com.esri.mo2.ui.bean
Class Tool

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--java.awt.Component
        |
        +--java.awt.Container
              |
              +--javax.swing.JComponent
                    |
                    +--com.esri.mo2.ui.bean.Tool
All Implemented Interfaces:
ImageObserver, MenuContainer, Serializable
Direct Known Subclasses:
BasePick, DragTool
public abstract class Tool
extends JComponent

Map Tools are components that can be added to a Map for the purpose of receiving and processing MouseListener Events that occur in the Map. You add a Tool to the Map using the Map's add() method (a Tool is a visual JFC "Swing" Component) so if the Tool is available as a Java Bean, you can do this at design time.

Any number of Tools can be added to a Map, butonly one Tool can be selected at any point in time, i.e. only the selected Tool will receive the mouse events.

Not necessarily all MouseEvents are passed to a Tool. The scope of MouseEvents is limited by the value of getMouseEventMask() which can be set by a Tool. By default, only "unadorned" left mouse button clicks are passed to a Tool, i.e. left-clicks without concurrently pressing any one of the Control, Shift, Alt or Meta keys. If you want to receive other button clicks, or exclude certain types of click, you need to override the getMouseEventMask() in your own Tool.

You select a tool by specifying it in the Map's setSelectedTool() method - this will automatically de-select whatever was the previously selected Map Tool.

If the Tool is not currently added to a Map, then invoking setSelectedTool() will automatically add the Tool to the Map.

A simple example might be a Tool that responds to a mouse click in the Map by performing a database inquiry and displaying identification information at that screen location (an Identify operation).

If you want a Tool that responds to MouseMotion events, then you need to subclass from RubberBandTool instead.

See Also:
Map.setSelectedTool(com.esri.mo2.ui.bean.Tool), Serialized Form

Field Detail

_map

protected Map _map
a reference to the current Map is made available to all Tools *after* the Tool has become selected. Therefore you should never try using this member variable in a Tool's constructor, but, you can begin to use it within the init() method.

DefaultCursor

public static final Cursor DefaultCursor
a mouse Cursor can be associated with a Tool, such that, when the Tool has been selected, and the mouse is moved into the Map component, that Cursor will be chosen. The Default_Cursor will be used if never specified.

Tool

public Tool()
Method Detail

isOpaque

public boolean isOpaque()
Tools are transparent

Overrides:
isOpaque in class JComponent

getMouseEventMask

protected int getMouseEventMask()
not necessarily all MouseEvents are passed to a Tool. Only those MouseEvents whose getModifiers() produces a non-zero value when logically ANDed with the value returned by this method.

By default, only "unadorned" left mouse button clicks are passed to a Tool, i.e. left-clicks without concurrently pressing any one of the Control, Shift, Alt or Meta keys.

Returns:
a combination of MouseEvent MASK values
See Also:
InputEvent

setMap

public void setMap(Map map)
the Map will call this method when the Tool is added to the Map

Parameters:
map - the Map that this Tool has just been added to

init

protected void init()
this method is invoked by the Map just after a Tool has been added to the Map, and is the appropriate place to include necessary Tool initialisations. Take care to include a super.init() first, in case your super-class also performs initialisations here (init() in this class does nothing)

setSelected

public void setSelected(boolean b)
this method is invoked by the Map just after a Tool has been selected, and is the appropriate place to initialise required event listeners.

When b==true, this Tool is added as a MouseListener to the Map. When b==false, this Tool is removed from being a MouseListener to the Map.

If you'd like to have your own Tool be a MouseMotionListener as well, you must override this method and do it yourself. If you do this, however, take care to include a super.setSelected() in your subclass code, so that the necessary super-class initialisations occur.

Parameters:
b - true == this Tool is now selected, false == has just become unselected
See Also:
DragTool.setSelected(boolean)

mouseClicked

public void mouseClicked(MouseEvent e)
this method is invoked whenever an end-user clicks in the Map. MouseEvents are filtered according to the current value of the MouseEventMask property. By default, this method does nothing.

Parameters:
e - the MouseEvent generated by the gesture
See Also:
getMouseEventMask(), MouseListener.mouseClicked(java.awt.event.MouseEvent)

mouseEntered

public void mouseEntered(MouseEvent e)
this method is invoked whenever an end-user moves the mouse "into" the Map. By default, this method sets the Tool's cursor, so take care to include a super.mouseEntered(e) if you want this behaviour.

Parameters:
e - the MouseEvent generated by the gesture
See Also:
MouseListener.mouseEntered(java.awt.event.MouseEvent)

mouseExited

public void mouseExited(MouseEvent e)
this method is invoked whenever an end-user moves the mouse away from the Map. By default, this method does nothing.

Parameters:
e - the MouseEvent generated by the gesture
See Also:
MouseListener.mouseExited(java.awt.event.MouseEvent)

mousePressed

public void mousePressed(MouseEvent e)
this method is invoked whenever an end-user presses the mouse button in the Map. MouseEvents are filtered according to the current value of the MouseEventMask property. By default, this method does nothing.

Parameters:
e - the MouseEvent generated by the gesture
See Also:
getMouseEventMask(), MouseListener.mousePressed(java.awt.event.MouseEvent)

mouseReleased

public void mouseReleased(MouseEvent e)
this method is invoked whenever an end-user releases the mouse button in the Map. MouseEvents are filtered according to the current value of the MouseEventMask property. By default, this method does nothing.

Parameters:
e - the MouseEvent generated by the gesture
See Also:
getMouseEventMask(), MouseListener.mouseReleased(java.awt.event.MouseEvent)
